etymologies: early 19th century (originally denoting the real or imitation sweets thrown during Italian carnivals): from Italian, literally ‘sweets’, from Latin confectum ‘something prepared’, neuter past participle of conficere ‘put together’ (see confect)

definitions: small pieces of colored paper thrown during a celebration such as a wedding.
shortDefinitions: small pieces of coloured paper traditionally thrown over bride and bridegroom by their wedding guests after marriage ceremony
